Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The Impact of Racially Traumatic Stressful Events on African Americans' Psychological, Physiological and Political Responses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General:

The purpose of this research is to investigate the effect of intra-racial differences among blacks on their physiological, psychological and political responses to Racially Traumatic Stressful Events (RTSEs). RTSEs are based on analogues consisting of visual imagery of the killings of unarmed blacks by police. The PI creates national model for understanding the effects of black intra-racial attitudes on the political attitudes and behaviors of African Americans. The PI creates two competing frameworks to better explain the impact of traumatic events on physiological responses by controlling for racial solidarity and negative racial attitudes and beliefs. The research diminishes the biases associated with social desirability responses found in explicit measures of the political responses of African Americans. The research uses elite interviews, focus groups, a national survey and a lab experiment to test the contention that the effects of racially traumatic stressful events on political behavior are conditioned by in-group racial and or ethnic attitudes.


Technical:

The purpose of this research is to investigate the effect of intra-racial differences among blacks on their physiological, psychological and political responses to Racially Traumatic Stressful Events (RTSEs). RTSEs are based on analogues consisting of visual imagery of the killings of unarmed blacks by police. A triangulation method is employed to collect qualitative, survey and physiological data. The PI creates two competing frameworks to better explain the impact of traumatic events on physiological responses by controlling for racial solidarity and negative racial attitudes and beliefs (linked fate versus intra-racial difference). The research diminishes the biases associated with social desirability responses found in explicit measures of the political responses of African Americans. The research uses elite interviews, focus groups, a national survey and a lab experiment to test the contention that the effects of racially traumatic stressful events on political behavior are conditioned by in-group racial and or ethnic attitudes. The specific aims are to: 1) explore whether the response to RTSE are episodic or foundations of social and political movements; 2) collect elite interview and survey data to examine the impact of RTSEs on psychological and political attitudes; 3) determine the impact of RTSEs on physiological responses using an experimental research design and 4) explore whether positive-and-negative explicit-and-implicit racial attitudes help to mitigate or exacerbate the political attitudes and political behaviors of African Americans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, the media have increased the coverage of unarmed African Americans killed by police. Here, these events are categorized as Racially Traumatic Stressful Events (RTSE), because of the trauma reported by those who either directly or indirectly witnessed these events. One does not have to be physically present to be negatively impacted. Given the increased use of social media, for example, African Americans have been repeatedly exposed to such events. This research explores the negative impact of these events using a physiological measure based on how much one sweats. This measurement has been traditionally found to be associated with the emotions of fear and anger. Psychological surveys are also used to measure African-Americans’ racial identity and social and political attitudes. In addition, implicit biases toward the police are used to measure one's negative or positive unconscious attitudes.

The field of political science has used physiological responses to analyze political attitudes of whites but not African Americans. Additionally, the field of psychology has examined racism as explained by physiological responses and racial identity; however, those studies have not included measurements of implicit biases nor political attitudes. 

The current research helps to fill these gaps by focusing on African Americans physiological responses to police as a function of implicit biases against the police, racial, social and political attitudes. This research used two approaches: 1) physiological responses; and 2) survey analyses. Both approaches used data collected from areas where police killings received national media coverage and those that have not received such coverage.  

The first approach uses data collected from an experiment focused on African Americans’ physiological responses to non-threatening images of police. For comparative purposes, these images were combined with neutral and threatening images and were randomly shown to the participants. Levels of sweat were used to measure negative emotional responses. The findings revealed that exposure to police increased arousals/responses among some African Americans, but not others. Among those who responded included African Americans who believed that the public holds African Americans in high regards, those who subscribed to Black Nationalists’ views, those who believed that the police in Ferguson, MO went too far and those who possessed negative implicit biases toward the police. Two of the variables, Black Nationalists’ views and Public Regard were not in the hypothesized direction. Black Nationalists may have followed the events so much that they have grown to become desensitized to RTSE and thus are better able to cope when seeing police. Those who possessed high levels of Public Regard may have been aroused because the recent police killings may have disrupted their ideas that the public in general holds African Americans in high regards.

The second approach used a convenience sample of roughly 600 African Americans. Based on the results, African Americans who lived in areas where police killings have received national media attention held negative subconscious biases toward the police when compared to those that did not receive such coverage. They were also angrier and possessed lower levels of trust in the police. Those who possessed low levels of trust in the police also held lower levels of American Identity.

The broader impact of this project included student engagement and presentations to the broader public in the community, from health-care to religious settings. The research was conducted at Jackson State University, a Historically Black University with an overwhelmingly African-American student body. Fifteen students from political science, computer science, biology, mas communication, business administration and psychology were recruited to serve as research assistants and encouraged to present their original research at conferences. Because of their mentorship and research experiences, four students were accepted into Research 1 political science PhD programs, one into a computer science M.S. program, and the remaining students were accepted into elite-level summer research programs. The impact of these successes has the potential to serve as a national model for increasing students of color in the PhD pipeline.

The research was also presented to communities outside of political science. For example, a presentation was conducted at the University of Mississippi Medical School, which lead to two medical students joining the research team and serving as mentors to undergraduates. The research was also presented at public forums, including churches. During these forums, conversations with members of the community focused on issues related to the traumatic stress of repeat viewing of episodes of violence against African Americans through sources such as social media. Issues of racial trauma relate to mental health as well as physical health and therefore needs to be addressed alongside the many health disparities among African Americans in the state of Mississippi and across the nation.
